21.
SESSION XX
MANUSCRIPT CULTURE
Session I was concerned with the cycle from pre-literate
to post-literate living. This was the shift from audible*
verbal* tribal* organization through the literate stages of
detribalization and new social structure to "post-literacy",
or electronics.
The whole Session may be dispensable, as also this one
on the manuscript. I say this because, should these two
Sessions be thought necessary, they would naturally have to
be expanded a great deal. They would also be supplied with
actual selections from various works, and not just reference
reading.
Manuscript culture was handicraft culture. Print was
the first true mechanization of an ancient handicraft. And
printing may have owed less to the handicrafts than to the
scholastic philosophers, with their insistence upon the uni¬
versality and, in a sense, the uniformity of all truth and
knowledge. For print gave material expression to this
universalism, uniting, as it has often been claimed, science
and democracy.
The fortunes of manuscript culture in the Nest fluctuated
with the supply of writing materials. David Diringsr°8
